title: in asm!() using a local numberic label made of all 0's and 1's gives a confusing error

labels.name: A-diagnostics
labels.description: Area: Messages for errors, warnings, and lints

labels.name: T-compiler
labels.description: Relevant to the compiler team, which will review and decide on the PR/issue.

labels.name: D-confusing
labels.description: Confusing diagnostic error that should be reworked

labels.name: D-newcomer-roadblock
labels.description: Confusing diagnostic error hard to understand for new users

body:
```
rustc 1.59.0 (9d1b2106e 2022-02-23)
```

Here's a function that jumps to a local numberic label inside of `asm!`:

```rust
use std::arch::asm;

#[cfg(target_arch = "x86_64")]
fn main() {
    let mut counter: u64 = 0;
    unsafe {
        asm!(
            "2:",
            "inc {counter}",
            "cmp {counter}, 10",
            "jnz 2b",
            counter = inout(reg) counter,
        );
    }
    dbg!(counter);  // prints 10
}
```

As per [Rust By Example](https://doc.rust-lang.org/nightly/rust-by-example/unsafe/asm.html#labels), we use `2:` as a local label there to work around an LLVM bug that mistakes labels like `0:`, `1:`, or `10:` for binary. This example works. However, if we don't know about this rule, and we try to use `0:` instead, the error we get is confusing:

```
error: invalid operand for instruction
  --> src/main.rs:11:14
   |
11 |             "jnz 0b",
   |              ^
   |
note: instantiated into assembly here
  --> <inline asm>:5:1
   |
5  | jnz 0b
   | ^

error: could not compile `scratch` due to previous error
```

Using `1:` is the same:

```
error: invalid operand for instruction
  --> src/main.rs:11:14
   |
11 |             "jnz 1b",
   |              ^
   |
note: instantiated into assembly here
  --> <inline asm>:5:1
   |
5  | jnz 1b
   | ^

error: could not compile `scratch` due to previous error
```

It would be pretty great to have a hint here like "`0:` and `1:` aren't valid local labels unfortunately, so just start with `2:`".
